a: the first letter of the alphabet
hale: (of a person, especially an elderly one) strong and healthy
half: either of two equal or corresponding parts into which something is or can be divided
hall: an area in a building onto which rooms open; a corridor.
idol: an image or representation of a god used as an object of worship.
halo: a disk or circle of light shown surrounding or above the head of a saint or holy person to represent their holiness.
pretend: speak and act so as to make it appear that something is the case when in fact it is not
wreck: the destruction of a ship at sea; a shipwreck
pick: take hold of and remove (a flower, fruit, or vegetable) from where it is growing
daring: (of a person or action) adventurous or audaciously bold
sake: for the purpose of; in the interest of; in order to achieve or preserve
hake: a large-headed elongated fish with long jaws and strong teeth. It is a valuable commercial food fish.
pica: a unit of type size and line length equal to 12 points (about 1\/6 inch or 4.2 mm).
snaffle: (on a bridle) a simple bit, typically a jointed one, used with a single set of reins.
hang: suspend or be suspended from above with the lower part dangling free
role: an actor's part in a play, movie, etc.
turf: grass and the surface layer of earth held together by its roots
vengeance: punishment inflicted or retribution exacted for an injury or wrong
cybernetics: the science of communications and automatic control systems in both machines and living things.
cliff: a steep rock face, especially at the edge of the sea
hank: a coil or skein of yarn, hair, rope, or other material
roll: move or cause to move in a particular direction by turning over and over on an axis
turn: move in a circular direction wholly or partly around an axis or point
turk: a native or inhabitant of Turkey, or a person of Turkish descent.
gold: a yellow precious metal, the chemical element of atomic number 79, used especially in jewelry and decoration and to guarantee the value of currencies.
golf: a game played on a large open-air course, in which a small hard ball is struck with a club into a series of small holes in the ground, the object being to use the fewest possible strokes to complete the course.
pier: a platform supported on pillars or girders leading out from the shore into a body of water, used as a landing stage for boats
umber: a natural pigment resembling but darker than ocher, normally dark yellowish-brown in color (raw umber) or dark brown when roasted (burnt umber).
wreak: cause (a large amount of damage or harm)
kirsch: brandy distilled from the fermented juice of cherries.
after: in the time following (an event or another period of time)
flip: turn over with a sudden quick movement
hand: the end part of a person's arm beyond the wrist, including the palm, fingers, and thumb
garland: a wreath of flowers and leaves, worn on the head or hung as a decoration.
salt: a white crystalline substance that gives seawater its characteristic taste and is used for seasoning or preserving food.
spiral: winding in a continuous and gradually widening (or tightening) curve, either around a central point on a flat plane or about an axis so as to form a cone
pied: having two or more different colors
blood: the red liquid that circulates in the arteries and veins of humans and other vertebrate animals, carrying oxygen to and carbon dioxide from the tissues of the body
halt: bring or come to an abrupt stop
sale: the exchange of a commodity for money; the action of selling something
tatted: (of a person or body part) tattooed, especially so that the skin is mostly or entirely covered
cancan: a lively, high-kicking stage dance originating in 19th-century Parisian music halls and performed by women in long skirts and petticoats
regain: obtain possession or use of (something) again after losing it
adrian: a city in southeastern Michigan; population 21,391 (est. 2008).
dogged: having or showing tenacity and grim persistence
plasma: the colorless fluid part of blood, lymph, or milk, in which corpuscles or fat globules are suspended.
raffia: a palm tree native to tropical Africa and Madagascar, with a short trunk and leaves that may grow up to 60 feet (18 m) long.
hyrax: a small herbivorous mammal with a compact body and a very short tail, found in arid country in Africa and Arabia. The nearest relatives to hyraxes are the elephants and other subungulates.
good: to be desired or approved of
muscat: a variety of white, red, or black grape with a musky scent, grown in warm climates for wine or raisins or as table grapes.
nonverbal: not involving or using words or speech
fiance: a man to whom someone is engaged to be married
gong: a metal disk with a turned rim, giving a resonant note when struck
romp: (especially of a child or animal) play roughly and energetically
dijon: an industrial city in eastern central France, the capital of Burgundy; population 155,340 (2006).
gumption: shrewd or spirited initiative and resourcefulness
myriad: a countless or extremely great number
mnemonic: a device such as a pattern of letters, ideas, or associations that assists in remembering something
aficionado: a person who is very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about an activity, subject, or pastime
laugh: make the spontaneous sounds and movements of the face and body that are the instinctive expressions of lively amusement and sometimes also of contempt or derision
glace: (of fruit) having a glossy surface due to preservation in sugar
rome: the capital of Italy, situated in the west central part of the country, on the Tiber River, about 16 miles (25 km) inland; population 2,724,347 (2008). According to tradition, the ancient city was founded by Romulus (after whom it is named) in 753 BC on the Palatine Hill; as it grew it spread to the other six hills of Rome (Aventine, Caelian, Capitoline, Esquiline, and Quirinal). Rome was made capital of a unified Italy in 1871.
cinder: a small piece of partly burned coal or wood that has stopped giving off flames but still has combustible matter in it.
erode: (of wind, water, or other natural agents) gradually wear away (soil, rock, or land)
tusk: a long, pointed tooth, especially one specially developed so as to protrude from the closed mouth, as in the elephant, walrus, or wild boar.
sane: (of a person) of sound mind; not mad or mentally ill
sand: a loose granular substance, typically pale yellowish brown, resulting from the erosion of siliceous and other rocks and forming a major constituent of beaches, riverbeds, the seabed, and deserts.
culvert: a tunnel carrying a stream or open drain under a road or railroad.
frustrate: prevent (a plan or attempted action) from progressing, succeeding, or being fulfilled
aside: to one side; out of the way
druid: a priest, magician, or soothsayer in the ancient Celtic religion.
anamorphic: denoting or relating to a distorted projection or drawing that appears normal when viewed from a particular point or with a suitable mirror or lens
harm: physical injury, especially that which is deliberately inflicted
neural: relating to a nerve or the nervous system
dexter: of, on, or toward the right-hand side (in a coat of arms, from the bearer's point of view, i.e., the left as it is depicted).
harp: a musical instrument, roughly triangular in shape, consisting of a frame supporting a graduated series of parallel strings, played by plucking with the fingers. The modern orchestral harp has an upright frame, with pedals that enable the strings to be retuned to different keys.
inmate: a person confined to an institution such as a prison or hospital
rope: a length of strong cord made by twisting together strands of natural fibers such as hemp or artificial fibers such as polypropylene
aboriginal: relating to the indigenous peoples of Australia or their languages
proactive: (of a person, policy, or action) creating or controlling a situation by causing something to happen rather than responding to it after it has happened
hart: an adult male deer, especially a red deer over five years old.
raring: very enthusiastic and eager to do something
olympia: a plain in Greece, in the western Peloponnese. In ancient Greece it was the site of the chief sanctuary of the god Zeus, the place where the original Olympic Games were held.
cohabit: live together and have a sexual relationship without being married.
lilac: a Eurasian shrub or small tree of the olive family, that has fragrant violet, pink, or white blossoms and is widely cultivated as an ornamental.
root: the part of a plant which attaches it to the ground or to a support, typically underground, conveying water and nourishment to the rest of the plant via numerous branches and fibers
croissant: a French crescent-shaped roll made of sweet flaky pastry, often eaten for breakfast.
hard: solid, firm, and rigid; not easily broken, bent, or pierced
hare: a fast-running, long-eared mammal that resembles a large rabbit, having long hind legs and occurring typically in grassland or open woodland.
sphincter: a ring of muscle surrounding and serving to guard or close an opening or tube, such as the anus or the openings of the stomach
roof: the structure forming the upper covering of a building or vehicle.
caliber: the quality of someone's character or the level of their ability
rook: a gregarious Eurasian crow with black plumage and a bare face, nesting in colonies in treetops.
room: space that can be occupied or where something can be done, especially viewed in terms of whether there is enough
verruca: a contagious and usually painful wart on the sole of the foot; a plantar wart.
tutu: a female ballet dancer's costume consisting of a bodice and an attached skirt incorporating numerous layers of fabric, this being either short and stiff and projecting horizontally from the waist (the classical tutu) or long, soft, and bell-shaped (the romantic tutu).
goon: a stupid, foolish, or eccentric person
tweed: a rough-surfaced woolen cloth, typically of mixed flecked colors, originally produced in Scotland
taking: the action or process of taking something
impeach: (especially in the US) charge (the holder of a public office) with misconduct
pile: a heap of things laid or lying one on top of another
pterodactyl: a pterosaur of the late Jurassic period, with a long slender head and neck and a very short tail.
sate: satisfy (a desire or an appetite) to the full
nitpick: engage in fussy or pedantic fault-finding
gosh: used to express surprise or give emphasis
pill: a small round mass of solid medicine to be swallowed whole.
burlesque: an absurd or comically exaggerated imitation of something, especially in a literary or dramatic work; a parody
sash: a long strip or loop of cloth worn over one shoulder or around the waist, especially as part of a uniform or official dress.
flop: fall, move, or hang in a heavy, loose, and ungainly way
hate: feel intense or passionate dislike for (someone)
flow: (of a fluid, gas, or electricity) move along or out steadily and continuously in a current or stream
gory: involving or showing violence and bloodshed
hasp: a slotted hinged metal plate that forms part of a fastening for a door or lid and is fitted over a metal loop and secured by a pin or padlock
pike: a long-bodied predatory freshwater fish with a pointed snout and large teeth, of both North America and Eurasia.
timid: showing a lack of courage or confidence; easily frightened
gore: blood that has been shed, especially as a result of violence
eider: a northern sea duck, of which the male has mainly black and white plumage with a colored head, and the brown female has soft down feathers that are used to line the nest.
flog: beat (someone) with a whip or stick as punishment or torture
phobia: an extreme or irrational fear of or aversion to something
sari: a garment consisting of a length of cotton or silk elaborately draped around the body, traditionally worn by women from South Asia.
sydney: the capital of New South Wales in southeastern Australia; population 4,399,722 (2008). It was the first British settlement in Australia and is the country's largest city and chief port. It has a fine natural harbor, crossed by the Sydney Harbour Bridge (opened 1932), and a striking opera house (opened 1973).
bacardi: a West Indian rum produced originally in Cuba.
ropy: resembling a rope, especially in being long, strong, and fibrous
anal: involving, relating to, or situated near the anus
ensue: happen or occur afterward or as a result
coach: a horse-drawn carriage, especially a closed one.
hash: a dish of cooked meat cut into small pieces and cooked again, usually with potatoes.
homage: special honor or respect shown publicly
jellied: (of food) set as or in a jelly
refract: (of water, air, or glass) make (a ray of light) change direction when it enters at an angle
pink: of a color intermediate between red and white, as of coral or salmon
pine: an evergreen coniferous tree that has clusters of long needle-shaped leaves. Many kinds are grown for their soft timber, which is widely used for furniture and pulp, or for tar and turpentine.
save: keep safe or rescue (someone or something) from harm or danger
muzak: recorded light background music played through speakers in public places.
pint: a unit of liquid or dry capacity equal to one half of a quart.
hotshot: an important or exceptionally able person
abscess: a swollen area within body tissue, containing an accumulation of pus
saul: (in the Bible) the first king of Israel (11th century BC).
rosy: (especially of a person's skin) colored like a pink or red rose, typically as an indication of health, youth, or embarrassment
surname: a hereditary name common to all members of a family, as distinct from a given name
ladle: a large long-handled spoon with a cup-shaped bowl, used for serving soup, stew, or sauce
rote: mechanical or habitual repetition of something to be learned
zirconium: the chemical element of atomic number 40, a hard silver-gray metal of the transition series.
kentucky: a state in the southeastern US; population 4,269,245 (est. 2008); capital, Frankfort. Ceded by the French to the British in 1763, it became the 15th state of the US in 1792.
rota: a list showing when each of a number of people has to do a particular job
energetic: showing or involving great activity or vitality
haul: (of a person) pull or drag with effort or force
pimp: a man who controls prostitutes and arranges clients for them, taking part of their earnings in return.
cotangent: (in a right-angled triangle) the ratio of the side (other than the hypotenuse) adjacent to a particular acute angle to the side opposite the angle.
praseodymium: the chemical element of atomic number 59, a soft silvery-white metal of the lanthanide series.
goth: a member of a Germanic people that invaded the Roman Empire from the east between the 3rd and 5th centuries. The eastern division, the Ostrogoths, founded a kingdom in Italy, while the Visigoths went on to found one in Spain.
reclaim: retrieve or recover (something previously lost, given, or paid); obtain the return of
corfu: a Greek island, one of the largest of the Ionian Islands, off the west coast of mainland Greece. It was known in ancient times as Corcyra; population 127,900 (est. 2009).
rose: a prickly bush or shrub that typically bears red, pink, yellow, or white fragrant flowers, native to north temperate regions. Numerous hybrids and cultivars have been developed and are widely grown as ornamentals.
eurasia: a term used to describe the combined continental landmass of Europe and Asia.
misquote: quote (a person or a piece of written or spoken text) inaccurately
kudos: praise and honor received for an achievement
orinoco: a river in northern South America that rises in southeastern Venezuela and flows 1,280 miles (2,060 km), entering the Atlantic Ocean through a vast delta. For part of its length it forms the border between Colombia and Venezuela.
quack: the characteristic harsh sound made by a duck
ezra: a Jewish priest and scribe who played a central part in the reform of Judaism in the 5th or 4th century BC, continuing the work of Nehemiah and forbidding mixed marriages.
madman: a man who is mentally ill.
bruise: an injury appearing as an area of discolored skin on the body, caused by a blow or impact rupturing underlying blood vessels
nougat: a candy made from sugar or honey, nuts, and egg white
alder: a widely distributed tree of the birch family which has toothed leaves and bears male catkins and woody female cones.
gown: a long dress, typically having a close-fitting bodice and a flared or flowing skirt, worn on formal occasions
rove: travel constantly without a fixed destination; wander
pipe: a tube of metal, plastic, or other material used to convey water, gas, oil, or other fluid substances.
pigeon: a stout seed- or fruit-eating bird with a small head, short legs, and a cooing voice, typically having gray and white plumage.
actress: a woman whose profession is acting on the stage, in movies, or on television
baltic: relating to the Baltic Sea or the region surrounding it.
pardon: the action of forgiving or being forgiven for an error or offense
pernicious: having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way
rout: a disorderly retreat of defeated troops
krakatoa: a small volcanic island in Indonesia that lies between Java and Sumatra. It was the scene of a great eruption in 1883 that destroyed most of the island.
gasket: a shaped piece or ring of rubber or other material sealing the junction between two surfaces in an engine or other device
anew: in a new or different and typically more positive way
cytochemistry: the chemistry of living cells, especially as studied microscopically.
peddle: try to sell (something, especially small goods) by going from house to house or place to place
ghent: a city in Belgium, capital of the province of East Flanders, on the Scheldt River; population 237,250 (2008).
gout: a disease in which defective metabolism of uric acid causes arthritis, especially in the smaller bones of the feet, deposition of chalkstones, and episodes of acute pain.
hawk: a bird of prey with broad rounded wings and a long tail, typically taking prey by surprise with a short chase.
goya: (1746‚\u20AC\u201C1828), Spanish painter and etcher; full name Francisco Jos√© de Goya y Lucientes. He is known for his works concerning the French occupation of Spain 1808‚\u20AC\u201C14, including The Shootings of May 3rd 1808 (1814) and The Disasters of War (1810‚\u20AC\u201C14), depicting the cruelty and horror of war.
bloat: make or become swollen with fluid or gas
bogie: an undercarriage with four or six wheels pivoted beneath the end of a railroad car.
haze: a slight obscuration of the lower atmosphere, typically caused by fine suspended particles
unteachable: (of a student or skill) unable to be taught
flux: the action or process of flowing or flowing out
becalm: leave (a sailing vessel) unable to move through lack of wind
ammunition: a supply or quantity of bullets and shells
twofold: twice as great or as numerous
ideological: based on or relating to a system of ideas and ideals, especially concerning economic or political theory and policy
flue: a duct for smoke and waste gases produced by a fire, a gas heater, a power station, or other fuel-burning installation
oregano: an aromatic plant related to marjoram, with leaves that are used fresh or dried as a culinary herb.
legume: a leguminous plant (member of the pea family), especially one grown as a crop
eire: the Gaelic name for Ireland, and the Irish name of the Republic of Ireland.
harness: a set of straps and fittings by which a horse or other draft animal is fastened to a cart, plow, etc. and is controlled by its driver.
sketch: a rough or unfinished drawing or painting, often made to assist in making a more finished picture

fatten: make or become fat or fatter
mayonnaise: a thick creamy dressing consisting of egg yolks beaten with oil and vinegar and seasoned
japan: a hard, dark, enamel-like varnish containing asphalt, used to give a black gloss to metal objects.
pity: the feeling of sorrow and compassion caused by the suffering and misfortunes of others
kumquat: an orange-like fruit related to the citruses, with an edible sweet rind and acid pulp.
pitt: the name of two British statesmen.
casaba: a winter melon of a variety with a wrinkled yellow rind and sweet flesh.
ordovician: relating to or denoting the second period of the Paleozoic era, between the Cambrian and Silurian periods
pith: spongy white tissue lining the rind of an orange, lemon, and other citrus fruits.
lovable: inspiring or deserving love or affection
state: the particular condition that someone or something is in at a specific time
jumble: an untidy collection or pile of things
element: a part or aspect of something abstract, especially one that is essential or characteristic
tonal: relating to the tone of music, color, or writing
synagogue: the building where a Jewish assembly or congregation meets for religious worship and instruction.
deputation: a group of people appointed to undertake a mission or take part in a formal process on behalf of a larger group
pisa: a city in northern Italy, in Tuscany, on the Arno River; population 87,398 (2008). It is noted for the Leaning Tower of Pisa, a circular bell tower that leans about 17 feet (5 m) from the perpendicular in its height of 181 feet (55 m).
valance: a length of decorative drapery attached to the canopy or frame of a bed in order to screen the structure or the space beneath it.
vanadium: the chemical element of atomic number 23, a hard gray metal of the transition series, used to make alloy steels.
fusible: able to be fused or melted easily.
swahili: a Bantu language widely used as a lingua franca in East Africa and having official status in several countries.
stave: a vertical wooden post or plank in a building or other structure
rheumatic: relating to or caused by rheumatism
dread: anticipate with great apprehension or fear
moment: a very brief period of time
mettle: a person's ability to cope well with difficulties or to face a demanding situation in a spirited and resilient way
tear: pull or rip (something) apart or to pieces with force
reissue: make a new supply or different form of (a product, especially a book or record) available for sale
worried: anxious or troubled about actual or potential problems
kitchen: a room or area where food is prepared and cooked.
ankle: the joint connecting the foot with the leg
stench: a strong and very unpleasant smell
teal: a small freshwater duck, typically with a greenish band on the wing that is most prominent in flight.
team: a group of players forming one side in a competitive game or sport
teak: hard durable timber used in shipbuilding and for making furniture.
geodesic: relating to or denoting the shortest possible line between two points on a sphere or other curved surface.
speech: the expression of or the ability to express thoughts and feelings by articulate sounds
watch: look at or observe attentively over a period of time
antwerp: a port in northern Belgium, on the Scheldt River; population 472,071 (2008). By the 16th century, it was a leading European commercial and financial center.
purple: a color intermediate between red and blue
hustings: a meeting at which candidates in an election address potential voters
urchin: a mischievous young child, especially one who is poorly or raggedly dressed
paunch: a large or protruding abdomen or stomach
litigant: a person involved in a lawsuit.
thigh: the part of the human leg between the hip and the knee.
anne: (1665‚\u20AC\u201C1714), queen of England and Scotland (known as Great Britain from 1707) and Ireland 1702‚\u20AC\u201C14. The last of the Stuart monarchs and daughter of the Catholic James II (but herself a Protestant), she succeeded her brother-in-law William III to the throne.
anna: a former monetary unit of India and Pakistan, equal to one sixteenth of a rupee.
frill: a strip of gathered or pleated material sewn by one side onto a garment or larger piece of material as a decorative edging or ornament.
glare: stare in an angry or fierce way
chrysanthemum: a plant of the daisy family with brightly colored ornamental flowers, existing in many cultivated varieties.
curvaceous: having an attractively curved shape (used especially of a woman or a woman's figure)
abbess: a woman who is the head of an abbey of nuns.
minaret: a tall slender tower, typically part of a mosque, with a balcony from which a muezzin calls Muslims to prayer.
rotogravure: a printing system using a rotary press with intaglio cylinders, typically running at high speed and used for long print runs of magazines and stamps
melilot: a fragrant herbaceous plant of the pea family, native to Eurasia and north Africa, now widespread and sometimes grown as forage or green manure.
actual: existing in fact; typically as contrasted with what was intended, expected, or believed
clatter: a continuous rattling sound as of hard objects falling or striking each other
dunce: a person who is slow at learning; a stupid person
gizmo: a gadget, especially one whose name the speaker does not know or cannot recall
misunderstand: fail to interpret or understand (something) correctly
trisect: divide (something) into three parts, typically three equal parts
pietism: pious sentiment, especially of an exaggerated or affected nature.
mezzo: a female singer with a voice pitched between soprano and contralto
solubility: the ability to be dissolved, especially in water
luminance: the intensity of light emitted from a surface per unit area in a given direction.
mellow: (especially of sound, taste, and color) pleasantly smooth or soft; free from harshness
askance: with an attitude or look of suspicion or disapproval
banish: send (someone) away from a country or place as an official punishment
defeasible: open in principle to revision, valid objection, forfeiture, or annulment.
house: a building for human habitation, especially one that is lived in by a family or small group of people
piezoelectric: relating to or involving electric polarization resulting from the application of mechanical stress
hitch: move (something) into a different position with a jerk
agnostic: a person who believes that nothing is known or can be known of the existence or nature of God or of anything beyond material phenomena; a person who claims neither faith nor disbelief in God.
sachet: a small perfumed bag used to scent clothes.
piton: a peg or spike driven into a rock or crack to support a climber or a rope.
shore: the land along the edge of a sea, lake, or other large body of water
bicker: argue about petty and trivial matters
bypass: a road passing around a town or its center to provide an alternative route for through traffic.
marvel: be filled with wonder or astonishment
disney: reminiscent of a film or theme park created by the Walt Disney Company, especially in being simplified, sanitized, or romanticized
knapsack: a bag with shoulder straps, carried on the back, and typically made of canvas or other weatherproof material.
turmeric: a bright yellow aromatic powder obtained from the rhizome of a plant of the ginger family, used for flavoring and coloring in Asian cooking and formerly as a fabric dye.
blemish: a small mark or flaw which spoils the appearance of something
enfranchise: give the right to vote to
feces: waste matter discharged from the bowels after food has been digested; excrement
rebecca: The (notional) leader of a movement whose supporters attacked and demolished turnpike toll gates chiefly in south and west Wales in the period between 1839‚\u20AC\u201C44 in protest at high tolls; (also) a member of such a group of protesters. In later use applied to similar groups carrying out other acts of social protest, especially organized salmon-poaching raids.
stash: store (something) safely and secretly in a specified place
inundate: overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with
abreast: side by side and facing the same way
funnel: a tube or pipe that is wide at the top and narrow at the bottom, used for guiding liquid or powder into a small opening.
facade: the face of a building, especially the principal front that looks onto a street or open space.
hanukkah: a lesser Jewish festival, lasting eight days from the 25th day of Kislev (in December) and commemorating the rededication of the Temple in 165 BC by the Maccabees after its desecration by the Syrians. It is marked by the successive kindling of eight lights.
taxonomy: the branch of science concerned with classification, especially of organisms; systematics.
extant: (especially of a document) still in existence; surviving
jasmine: an Old World shrub or climbing plant that bears fragrant flowers used in perfumery or tea. It is popular as an ornamental.
cryogenic: relating to or involving the branch of physics that deals with the production and effects of very low temperatures
anathema: something or someone that one vehemently dislikes
gavotte: a medium-paced French dance, popular in the 18th century.
inlet: a small arm of the sea, a lake, or a river.
omega: the twenty-fourth, and last, letter of the Greek alphabet (Œ©, œ\u2030), transliterated as ‚\u20ACòo‚\u20ACô or ‚\u20ACò≈?.‚\u20ACô.
coast: the part of the land near the sea; the edge of the land
satchel: a bag carried on the shoulder by a long strap and typically closed by a flap.
tonic: a medicinal substance taken to give a feeling of vigor or well-being.
sisal: a Mexican agave with large fleshy leaves, cultivated for fiber production.
vetchling: a widely distributed scrambling plant related to the vetches, typically having fewer leaflets.
dacha: a country house or cottage in Russia, typically used as a second or vacation home.
tomography: a technique for displaying a representation of a cross section through a human body or other solid object using X-rays or ultrasound.
acyclic: not displaying or forming part of a cycle.
agronomy: the science of soil management and crop production.
crutch: a long stick with a crosspiece at the top, used as a support under the armpit by a person with an injury or disability.
hound: a dog of a breed used for hunting, especially one able to track by scent.
evince: reveal the presence of (a quality or feeling)
furor: an outbreak of public anger or excitement
ante: a stake put up by a player in poker and similar games before receiving cards
agoraphobia: extreme or irrational fear of entering open or crowded places, of leaving one's own home, or of being in places from which escape is difficult.
fetch: go for and then bring back (someone or something) for someone
percale: a closely woven fine cotton or polyester fabric used especially for sheets
oasis: a fertile spot in a desert, where water is found
flurried: (of a person) agitated, nervous, or anxious
compact: closely and neatly packed together; dense
tell: communicate information, facts, or news to someone in spoken or written words
irrigate: supply water to (land or crops) to help growth, typically by means of channels.
medusa: a free-swimming sexual form of a coelenterate such as a jellyfish, typically having an umbrella-shaped body with stinging tentacles around the edge. In some species, medusae are a phase in the life cycle which alternates with a polypoid phase.
purgation: the purification or cleansing of someone or something
jordan: a country in the Middle East, east of the River Jordan; population 7,600,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Arabic; capital, Amman.

artwork: illustrations, photographs, or other nontextual material prepared for inclusion in a publication
water: a colorless, transparent, odorless liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain and is the basis of the fluids of living organisms

Infamous for his cruelty, he ordered the murder of his mother Agrippina in 59 and wantonly executed leading Romans. His reign witnessed a fire that destroyed half of Rome in 64. A wave of uprisings in 68 led to his flight from Rome and his eventual suicide.

thin: having opposite surfaces or sides close together; of little thickness or depth

clique: a small group of people, with shared interests or other features in common, who spend time together and do not readily allow others to join them
quake: (especially of the earth) shake or tremble
silhouette: the dark shape and outline of someone or something visible against a lighter background, especially in dim light
know: be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information
knot: a fastening made by tying a piece of string, rope, or something similar
tontine: an annuity shared by subscribers to a loan or common fund, the shares increasing as subscribers die until the last survivor enjoys the whole income.
ingenious: (of a person) clever, original, and inventive
populace: the people living in a particular country or area
maoism: the communist doctrines of Mao Zedong as formerly practiced in China, having as a central idea permanent revolution and stressing the importance of the peasantry, small-scale industry, and agricultural collectivization.
thwack: strike forcefully with a sharp blow
snack: a small amount of food eaten between meals
apron: a protective or decorative garment worn over the front of one's clothes and tied at the back
privacy: the state or condition of being free from being observed or disturbed by other people
gruff: (of a voice) rough and low in pitch
curfew: a regulation requiring people to remain indoors between specified hours, typically at night
quail: a small, short-tailed Old World game bird resembling a small partridge, typically having brown camouflaged plumage.
osmosis: a process by which molecules of a solvent tend to pass through a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution into a more concentrated one, thus equalizing the concentrations on each side of the membrane.
cringe: bend one's head and body in fear or in a servile manner
heir: a person legally entitled to the property or rank of another on that person's death
shriek: utter a high-pitched piercing sound or words, especially as an expression of terror, pain, or excitement
psalm: a sacred song or hymn, in particular any of those contained in the biblical Book of Psalms and used in Christian and Jewish worship
airmail: a system of transporting mail by aircraft, typically overseas
truancy: the action of staying away from school without good reason; absenteeism
hawaii: a state of the US comprising a group of over twenty islands in the North Pacific Ocean; capital, Honolulu (on Oahu); population 1,288,198 (est. 2008). First settled by Polynesians, Hawaii was visited by Captain James Cook in 1778. It was annexed by the US in 1898 and became the 50th state in 1959.
xerography: a dry copying process in which black or colored powder adheres to parts of a surface remaining electrically charged after being exposed to light from an image of the document to be copied.
zenith: the time at which something is most powerful or successful
timor: the largest of the Lesser Sunda Islands, in the southern Malay Archipelago. The island was formerly divided into Dutch West Timor and Portuguese East Timor. In 1950, West Timor was absorbed into the newly formed Republic of Indonesia. In 1975, East Timor declared itself independent but was invaded and occupied by Indonesia; it finally became an independent state in 2002.
gruel: a thin liquid food of oatmeal or other meal boiled in milk or water.
peafowl: a large crested pheasant native to Asia.
bladder: a membranous sac in humans and other animals, in which urine is collected for excretion
smock: a loose dress or blouse, with the upper part closely gathered in smocking.
maori: a member of the indigenous people of New Zealand.
gannet: a large seabird with mainly white plumage, known for catching fish by plunge-diving.
type: a category of people or things having common characteristics
beyond: at or to the further side of
hell: a place regarded in various religions as a spiritual realm of evil and suffering, often traditionally depicted as a place of perpetual fire beneath the earth where the wicked are punished after death
helm: a tiller or wheel and any associated equipment for steering a ship or boat
ontario: a province in eastern Canada, between Hudson Bay and the Great Lakes; population 12,160,282 (2006); capital, Toronto. It was settled by the French and the English in the 1600s, ceded to Britain in 1763, and became one of the original four provinces in the Dominion of Canada in 1867.
skiff: a shallow, flat-bottomed open boat with sharp bow and square stern.
madagascar: an island country in the Indian Ocean, off the eastern coast of Africa; 24,200,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Antananarivo; official languages, Malagasy and French.
proof: evidence or argument establishing or helping to establish a fact or the truth of a statement
cayenne: a pungent hot-tasting red powder prepared from ground dried chili peppers.
hospice: a home providing care for the sick or terminally ill
harbinger: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another
phase: a distinct period or stage in a series of events or a process of change or development
culpability: responsibility for a fault or wrong; blame
pygmalion: a king of Cyprus who fashioned an ivory statue of a beautiful woman and loved it so deeply that in answer to his prayer Aphrodite gave it life. The woman (at some point named Galatea) bore him a daughter, Paphos.
procedural: relating to an established or official way of doing something
joist: a length of timber or steel supporting part of the structure of a building, typically arranged in parallel series to support a floor or ceiling.
shilling: a former British coin and monetary unit equal to one twentieth of a pound or twelve pence.
befriend: act as a friend to (someone) by offering help or support
axial: of, forming, or relating to an axis
assail: make a concerted or violent attack on
chock: a wedge or block placed against a wheel or rounded object, to prevent it from moving
fabric: cloth or other material produced by weaving or knitting fibers
argon: the chemical element of atomic number 18, an inert gaseous element of the noble gas group. Argon is the most common noble gas, making up nearly one percent of the earth's atmosphere.
belch: emit gas noisily from the stomach through the mouth
fewness: The quality or fact of being few in number; small number; scantiness in number.
force: strength or energy as an attribute of physical action or movement
calcification: the hardening of tissue or other material by the deposition of or conversion into calcium carbonate or some other insoluble calcium compounds
patagonia: a region of South America, in southern Argentina and Chile. Consisting largely of a dry barren plateau, it extends from the Colorado River in central Argentina to the Strait of Magellan and from the Andes to the Atlantic coast.
ecuador: a republic in northwestern South America, on the Pacific coast; population 16,100,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Quito; languages, Spanish (official), Quechua.
honiara: a port and the capital of the Solomon Islands, situated on the northwestern coast of the island of Guadalcanal; population 66,000 (est. 2007).
caprice: a sudden and unaccountable change of mood or behavior
north: the direction in which a compass needle normally points, toward the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east, or the part of the horizon lying in this direction
vagabond: a person who wanders from place to place without a home or job.
boogie: a style of blues played on the piano with a strong, fast beat
sedentary: (of a person) tending to spend much time seated; somewhat inactive
eminence: fame or recognized superiority, especially within a particular sphere or profession
hemp: the cannabis plant, especially when grown for fiber.
sewing: the action or activity of sewing
power: the ability to do something or act in a particular way, especially as a faculty or quality
ulterior: existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; intentionally hidden
bridal: of or concerning a bride or a wedding
sell: give or hand over (something) in exchange for money
suspect: have an idea or impression of the existence, presence, or truth of (something) without certain proof
abide: accept or act in accordance with (a rule, decision, or recommendation)
help: make it easier for (someone) to do something by offering one's services or resources
bigot: a person who is obstinately or unreasonably attached to a belief, opinion, or faction, especially one who is prejudiced against or antagonistic toward a person or people on the basis of their membership of a particular group
smudge: cause (something) to become messily smeared by rubbing it
mingle: mix or cause to mix together
braid: threads of silk, cotton, or other material woven into a decorative band for edging or trimming garments
endgame: the final stage of a game such as chess or bridge, when few pieces or cards remain
self: a person's essential being that distinguishes them from others, especially considered as the object of introspection or reflexive action
prone: likely to or liable to suffer from, do, or experience something, typically something regrettable or unwelcome
gabon: a country in West Africa, on the Atlantic coast; population 1,700,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Libreville; languages, French (official) and West African languages. Gabon became a French territory in 1888. Part of French Equatorial Africa from 1910 to 1958, it declared independence in 1960.
dallas: a city in northeastern Texas, noted as a center of the oil industry; population 1,279,910 (est. 2008). President John F. Kennedy was assassinated here in November 1963.
snail: a mollusk with a single spiral shell into which the whole body can be withdrawn.
cobra: a highly venomous snake native to Africa and Asia that spreads the skin of its neck into a hood when disturbed.
earful: a prolonged amount of talking, typically an angry reprimand
panda: a large bearlike mammal with characteristic black and white markings, native to certain mountain forests in China. It feeds almost entirely on bamboo and has become increasingly rare.
onion: an edible bulb with a pungent taste and smell, composed of several concentric layers, used in cooking
eucalyptus: a fast-growing evergreen Australasian tree that has been widely introduced elsewhere. It is valued for its timber, oil, gum, resin, and as an ornamental tree.
pavilion: a summerhouse or other decorative building used as a shelter in a park or large garden.
gable: the part of a wall that encloses the end of a pitched roof
recalcitrant: having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline
proud: feeling deep pleasure or satisfaction as a result of one's own achievements, qualities, or possessions or those of someone with whom one is closely associated
brace: a device fitted to something, in particular a weak or injured part of the body, to give support
nuisance: a person, thing, or circumstance causing inconvenience or annoyance
prurient: having or encouraging an excessive interest in sexual matters
arcing: the formation of an electric arc
igneous: (of rock) having solidified from lava or magma.
reaffirm: state again as a fact; assert again strongly
send: cause to go or be taken to a particular destination; arrange for the delivery of, especially by mail
fitful: active or occurring spasmodically or intermittently; not regular or steady
here: in, at, or to this place or position
snake: a long limbless reptile which has no eyelids, a short tail, and jaws that are capable of considerable extension. Some snakes have a venomous bite.
hero: a priestess of Aphrodite at Sestos on the European shore of the Hellespont, whose lover Leander, a youth of Abydos on the opposite shore, swam the strait nightly to visit her. One stormy night he was drowned and Hero in grief threw herself into the sea.
gimlet: a small T-shaped tool with a screw-tip for boring holes.
hers: used to refer to a thing or things belonging to or associated with a female person or animal previously mentioned
aggrandize: increase the power, status, or wealth of
omnibus: a volume containing several novels or other items previously published separately
buck: the male of some horned animals, especially the fallow deer, roe deer, reindeer, and antelopes.
asynchronous: (of two or more objects or events) not existing or happening at the same time.
iceberg: a large floating mass of ice detached from a glacier or ice sheet and carried out to sea.
feeble: lacking physical strength, especially as a result of age or illness
herb: any plant with leaves, seeds, or flowers used for flavoring, food, medicine, or perfume
herd: a large group of animals, especially hoofed mammals, that live, feed, or migrate together or are kept together as livestock
sputnik: each of a series of Soviet artificial satellites, the first of which (launched on October 4, 1957) was the first satellite to be placed in orbit.
smoke: a visible suspension of carbon or other particles in air, typically one emitted from a burning substance
milwaukee: an industrial port and city in southeastern Wisconsin, on the western shore of Lake Michigan; population 604,477 (est. 2008). It is noted for its brewing industry and is an important port on the St. Lawrence Seaway.
trireme: an ancient Greek or Roman war galley with three banks of oars.
tuvalu: a country in the southwestern Pacific Ocean consisting of a group of nine main islands, formerly called the Ellice Islands; population 10,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, English and Tuvaluan (local Austronesian language); capital, Funafuti. The islands formed part of the British colony of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands but separated from the Gilberts after a referendum in 1975. Tuvalu became independent within the Commonwealth of Nations in 1978.
tyler: an industrial city in eastern Texas, noted for its roses; population 97,705 (est. 2008).
mausoleum: a building, especially a large and stately one, housing a tomb or tombs
subversion: the undermining of the power and authority of an established system or institution
astute: having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations or people and turn this to one's advantage
humdrum: lacking excitement or variety; dull; monotonous
ounce: a unit of weight of one sixteenth of a pound avoirdupois (approximately 28 grams)
emit: produce and discharge (something, especially gas or radiation)
emir: a title of various Muslim (mainly Arab) rulers
geisha: a Japanese hostess trained to entertain men with conversation, dance, and song
anthem: a rousing or uplifting song identified with a particular group, body, or cause
almanac: an annual calendar containing important dates and statistical information such as astronomical data and tide tables.
seismic: relating to earthquakes or other vibrations of the earth and its crust
encumber: restrict or burden (someone or something) in such a way that free action or movement is difficult
youth: the period between childhood and adult age
carcass: the dead body of an animal
hiccup: an involuntary spasm of the diaphragm and respiratory organs, with a sudden closure of the glottis and a characteristic sound like that of a cough.
virgin: a person who has never had sexual intercourse
fluctuate: rise and fall irregularly in number or amount
rehearsal: a practice or trial performance of a play or other work for later public performance
thus: as a result or consequence of this; therefore
thug: a violent, aggressive person, especially one who is a criminal
deflate: let air or gas out of (a tire, balloon, or similar object)
serf: an agricultural laborer bound under the feudal system to work on their lord's estate.
evacuate: remove (someone) from a place of danger to a safer place
thud: a dull, heavy sound, such as that made by an object falling to the ground
upthrust: the upward force that a liquid or gas exerts on a body floating in it.
junta: a military or political group that rules a country after taking power by force
much: a great amount or quantity of
arab: a member of a Semitic people, originally from the Arabian peninsula and neighboring territories, inhabiting much of the Middle East and North Africa.
tadpole: the tailed aquatic larva of an amphibian (frog, toad, newt, or salamander), breathing through gills and lacking legs until the later stages of its development.
poise: graceful and elegant bearing in a person
appalachian: relating to or characteristic of the Appalachian Mountains in eastern North America.
trellis: a framework of light wooden or metal bars, chiefly used as a support for fruit trees or climbing plants.
cider: an unfermented drink made by crushing fruit, typically apples.
vancouver: a city and port in British Columbia, in southwestern Canada, on the mainland opposite Vancouver Island; population 578,041 (2006). It is the largest city and chief port in western Canada.
maelstrom: a powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river.
prying: excessively interested in a person's private affairs; too inquisitive
newcastle: an industrial city in northeastern England, a port on the Tyne River; population 170,200 (est. 2009). Full name Newcastle upon Tyne.
muff: a tube made of fur or other warm material into which the hands are placed for warmth.
maser: a device using the stimulated emission of radiation by excited atoms to amplify or generate coherent monochromatic electromagnetic radiation in the microwave range.
webbed: (of the feet of a swimming bird or other aquatic animal) having the toes connected by a membrane.
anode: the positively charged electrode by which the electrons leave a device.
firkin: a small cask formerly used for liquids, butter, or fish.
union: the action or fact of joining or being joined, especially in a political context
seth: an evil god who murdered his brother Osiris and wounded Osiris's son Horus. Seth is represented as having the head of an animal with a long pointed snout.
encephalitis: inflammation of the brain, caused by infection or an allergic reaction.
wraf: Women's Royal Air Force (in the UK, until 1994).
adage: a proverb or short statement expressing a general truth
arch: a curved symmetrical structure spanning an opening and typically supporting the weight of a bridge, roof, or wall above it.
wrap: cover or enclose (someone or something) in paper or soft material
novel: a fictitious prose narrative of book length, typically representing character and action with some degree of realism
cremate: dispose of (a dead person's body) by burning it to ashes, typically after a funeral ceremony
lepidolite: a mineral of the mica group containing lithium, typically gray or lilac in color.
slosh: (of liquid in a container) move irregularly with a splashing sound
kobe: a port in central Japan, on the island of Honshu; population 1,502,772 (2007). The city was severely damaged by an earthquake in 1995.
enlarge: make or become bigger or more extensive
dapper: neat and trim in dress and appearance (typically used of a man)
jakarta: the capital of Indonesia, in northwestern Java; population 9,125,000 (est. 2009).
area: a region or part of a town, a country, or the world
dogfish: a small sand-colored bottom-dwelling shark with a long tail, common on European coasts.
murder: the unlawful premeditated killing of one human being by another
nirvana: (in Buddhism) a transcendent state in which there is neither suffering, desire, nor sense of self, and the subject is released from the effects of karma and the cycle of death and rebirth. It represents the final goal of Buddhism.
risque: slightly indecent and liable to shock, especially by being sexually suggestive
torus: a surface or solid formed by rotating a closed curve, especially a circle, around a line that lies in the same plane but does not intersect it (e.g., like a ring-shaped doughnut).
visibility: the state of being able to see or be seen
lace: a fine open fabric, typically one of cotton or silk, made by looping, twisting, or knitting thread in patterns and used especially for trimming garments
outface: disconcert or defeat (an opponent) by bold confrontation
biograph: A biography or biographical article; especially a short profile of a public figure.
senegal: a country on the coast of West Africa; population 15,100,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Dakar; languages, French (official), Wolof, and other West African languages.
marmalade: a sweet food made from citrus fruit (especially bitter oranges) and sugar boiled to a thick consistency, usually eaten spread on toast
lack: the state of being without or not having enough of something
toast: sliced bread browned on both sides by exposure to radiant heat
brunch: a late morning meal eaten instead of breakfast and lunch
misjudge: form a wrong opinion or conclusion about
illogic: reasoning or thought which is not logical.
jangle: make or cause to make a ringing metallic sound, typically a discordant one
siesta: an afternoon rest or nap, especially one taken during the hottest hours of the day in a hot climate
young: having lived or existed for only a short time
avenge: inflict harm in return for (an injury or wrong done to oneself or another)
gasoline: refined petroleum used as fuel for internal combustion engines.
lipid: any of a class of organic compounds that are fatty acids or their derivatives and are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents. They include many natural oils, waxes, and steroids.
quiche: a baked flan or tart with a savory filling thickened with eggs
pyromania: an obsessive desire to set fire to things.
basra: an oil port of Iraq, on the Shatt al-Arab waterway; population 870,000 (est. 2007).
eloquence: fluent or persuasive speaking or writing
foxing: discoloration of the paper of old books or prints with brown spots
caffeine: a crystalline compound that is found especially in tea and coffee plants and is a stimulant of the central nervous system.
forlorn: pitifully sad and abandoned or lonely
conakry: the capital and chief port of Guinea, in the western part of the county, on the Atlantic coast; population 1,484,000 (est. 2007).
redneck: a working-class white person, especially a politically reactionary one from a rural area
inkling: a slight knowledge or suspicion; a hint
evolution: the process by which different kinds of living organisms are thought to have developed and diversified from earlier forms during the history of the earth.
acupuncture: a form of complementary medicine that involves pricking the skin or tissues with needles, used to alleviate pain and to treat various physical, mental, and emotional conditions. Originating in ancient China, acupuncture is now widely practiced in the West.
taint: a trace of a bad or undesirable quality or substance
wren: a small short-winged songbird found chiefly in the New World.
pinnacle: the most successful point; the culmination
ethos: the characteristic spirit of a culture, era, or community as manifested in its beliefs and aspirations
lady: a woman (used as a polite or old-fashioned form of reference)
ulcer: an open sore on an external or internal surface of the body, caused by a break in the skin or mucous membrane that fails to heal.
magazine: a periodical publication containing articles and illustrations, typically covering a particular subject or area of interest
wade: walk with effort through water or another liquid or viscous substance
inject: drive or force (a liquid, especially a drug or vaccine) into a person or animal's body with a syringe or similar device
placard: a poster or sign for public display, either fixed to a wall or carried during a demonstration.
pocket: a small bag sewn into or on clothing so as to form part of it, used for carrying small articles
anoint: smear or rub with oil, typically as part of a religious ceremony
albania: a republic in southeastern Europe, bordering on the Adriatic Sea; population 2,900,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Albanian; capital, Tirana.
cutter: a person or thing that cuts something.
focus: the center of interest or activity
hamper: a large basket with a lid used for laundry
wrist: the joint connecting the hand with the forearm
doting: extremely and uncritically fond of someone; adoring
usher: a person who shows people to their seats, especially in a theater or at a wedding.
anachronism: a thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned
mule: the offspring of a donkey and a horse (strictly, a male donkey and a female horse), typically sterile and used as a beast of burden.
tetanus: a bacterial disease marked by rigidity and spasms of the voluntary muscles.
genteel: polite, refined, or respectable, often in an affected or ostentatious way
bump: a light blow or a jolting collision
seaquake: a sudden disturbance of the sea caused by a submarine eruption or earthquake.
ordain: make (someone) a priest or minister; confer holy orders on
mull: think about (a fact, proposal, or request) deeply and at length
basle: a commercial and industrial city on the Rhine in northwestern Switzerland; population 163,521 (2007).
sneer: a contemptuous or mocking smile, remark, or tone
wage: a fixed regular payment, typically paid on a daily or weekly basis, made by an employer to an employee, especially to a manual or unskilled worker
layup: a one-handed shot made from near the basket, especially one that rebounds off the backboard.
arid: (of land or a climate) having little or no rain; too dry or barren to support vegetation
fiber: a thread or filament from which a vegetable tissue, mineral substance, or textile is formed
taffeta: a fine lustrous silk or similar synthetic fabric with a crisp texture.
aria: a long accompanied song for a solo voice, typically one in an opera or oratorio.
bulb: a rounded underground storage organ present in some plants, notably those of the lily family, consisting of a short stem surrounded by fleshy scale leaves or leaf bases, lying dormant over winter.
belvedere: a summerhouse or open-sided gallery, usually at rooftop level, commanding a fine view.
picnic: an outing or occasion that involves taking a packed meal to be eaten outdoors
eardrum: the membrane of the middle ear, which vibrates in response to sound waves; the tympanic membrane.
upbeat: (in music) an unaccented beat preceding an accented beat.
waft: pass or cause to pass easily or gently through or as if through the air
winner: a person or thing that wins something
erotic: relating to or tending to arouse sexual desire or excitement
aril: an extra seed-covering, typically colored and hairy or fleshy, e.g., the red fleshy cup around a yew seed.
bulk: the mass or magnitude of something large
despair: the complete loss or absence of hope
hundred: the number equivalent to the product of ten and ten; ten more than ninety; 100
wait: stay where one is or delay action until a particular time or until something else happens
queen: the female ruler of an independent state, especially one who inherits the position by right of birth
locomotion: movement or the ability to move from one place to another
joyride: a ride for enjoyment in a vehicle or aircraft.
waif: a homeless, neglected, or abandoned person, especially a child
sibilant: making or characterized by a hissing sound
niobium: the chemical element of atomic number 41, a silver-gray metal of the transition series, used in superconducting alloys.
unchain: remove the chains fastening or securing (someone or something)
wail: a prolonged high-pitched cry of pain, grief, or anger
bung: a stopper for closing a hole in a container.
jostle: push, elbow, or bump against (someone) roughly, typically in a crowd
lair: a place where a wild animal, especially a fierce or dangerous one, lives
bayonet: a blade that may be fixed to the muzzle of a rifle and used to stab an opponent in hand-to-hand fighting.
scribble: write or draw (something) carelessly or hurriedly
writ: a form of written command in the name of a court or other legal authority to act, or abstain from acting, in some way.
bunk: a narrow shelflike bed, typically one of two or more arranged one on top of the other.
practicability: the quality of being practicable; viability
tide: the alternate rising and falling of the sea, usually twice in each lunar day at a particular place, due to the attraction of the moon and sun
associate: connect (someone or something) with something else in one's mind
rupee: the basic monetary unit of India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Mauritius, and the Seychelles, equal to 100 paise in India, Pakistan, and Nepal, and 100 cents in Sri Lanka, Mauritius, and the Seychelles.
gleam: shine brightly, especially with reflected light
detract: diminish the worth or value of (a quality or achievement)
wake: emerge or cause to emerge from a state of sleep; stop sleeping
hosanna: (especially in biblical, Judaic, and Christian use) used to express adoration, praise, or joy
twirl: spin quickly and lightly around, especially repeatedly
sneak: move or go in a furtive or stealthy manner
swat: hit or crush (something, especially an insect) with a sharp blow from a flat object
beneath: extending or directly underneath, typically with close contact
libation: a drink poured out as an offering to a deity
ritual: a religious or solemn ceremony consisting of a series of actions performed according to a prescribed order
swap: take part in an exchange of
swan: a large waterbird with a long flexible neck, short legs, webbed feet, a broad bill, and typically all-white plumage.
sway: move or cause to move slowly or rhythmically backward and forward or from side to side
tick: a regular short, sharp sound, especially that made by a clock or watch.
munich: a city in southeastern Germany, capital of Bavaria; population 1,294,600 (est. 2006).
tutor: a private teacher, typically one who teaches a single student or a very small group
army: an organized military force equipped for fighting on land
ammeter: an instrument for measuring electric current in amperes.
swab: an absorbent pad or piece of material, often on a stick or rod, used in surgery and medicine for cleaning wounds and skin, applying medication, or taking specimens.
ethic: a set of moral principles, especially ones relating to or affirming a specified group, field, or form of conduct
october: the tenth month of the year, in the northern hemisphere usually considered the second month of autumn
nuncio: (in the Roman Catholic Church) a papal ambassador to a foreign court or government.
basic: forming an essential foundation or starting point; fundamental
swag: a curtain or piece of fabric fastened so as to hang in a drooping curve.
lake: a large body of water surrounded by land
twist: form into a bent, curling, or distorted shape
jehovah: a form of the Hebrew name of God used in some translations of the Bible.
tiff: a petty quarrel, especially one between friends or lovers
nuance: a subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound
vole: a small, typically burrowing, mouse-like rodent with a rounded muzzle, found in both Eurasia and North America.
abdomen: the part of the body of a vertebrate containing the digestive organs; the belly. In humans and other mammals, it is bounded by the diaphragm and the pelvis.
bush: a shrub or clump of shrubs with stems of moderate length
muse: (in Greek and Roman mythology) each of nine goddesses, the daughters of Zeus and Mnemosyne, who preside over the arts and sciences.
plywood: a type of strong thin wooden board consisting of two or more layers glued and pressed together with the direction of the grain alternating, and usually sold in sheets of four by eight feet
dryly: in a matter-of-fact or ironically humorous way
gizzard: a muscular, thick-walled part of a bird's stomach for grinding food, typically with grit.
tier: a row or level of a structure, typically one of a series of rows placed one above the other and successively receding or diminishing in size
busy: having a great deal to do
extra: added to an existing or usual amount or number; additional
cuckold: a man whose wife is sexually unfaithful, regarded as an object of derision
land: the part of the earth's surface that is not covered by water, as opposed to the sea or the air
bust: a sculpture of a person's head, shoulders, and chest

lane: a narrow road, especially in a rural area
burn: (of a fire) produce flames and heat while consuming a material such as coal or wood
wring: squeeze and twist (something) to force liquid from it

lamp: a device for giving light, either one consisting of an electric bulb together with its holder and shade or cover, or one burning gas or a liquid fuel and consisting of a wick or mantle and a glass shade
maraca: a percussion instrument in the form of a hollow gourd or gourd-shaped container filled with dried beans or similar objects and played, usually in pairs, by being shaken.
choral: composed for or sung by a choir or chorus
pebble: a small stone made smooth and round by the action of water or sand
palfrey: a docile horse used for ordinary riding, especially by women.
wall: a continuous vertical brick or stone structure that encloses or divides an area of land
walk: move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once
burp: noisily release air from the stomach through the mouth; belch.
lame: (especially of an animal) unable to walk without difficulty as the result of an injury or illness affecting the leg or foot
gymkhana: a day event comprising races and other competitions between horse riders or car drivers.
crofter: a person who farms a croft.
penknife: a small pocketknife with a blade that folds into the handle.
acorn: the fruit of the oak tree, a smooth oval nut in a rough cup-shaped base.
oncology: the study and treatment of tumors.
helen: the daughter of Zeus and Leda, born from an egg. In the Homeric poems she was the outstandingly beautiful wife of Menelaus, and her abduction by Paris (to whom she had been promised, as a bribe, by Aphrodite) led to the Trojan War.
crook: the hooked staff of a shepherd
cuboid: more or less cubic in shape
camaraderie: mutual trust and friendship among people who spend a lot of time together
drift: be carried slowly by a current of air or water
mankind: human beings considered collectively; the human race
diathermy: a medical and surgical technique involving the production of heat in a part of the body by high-frequency electric currents, to stimulate the circulation, relieve pain, destroy unhealthy tissue, or cause bleeding vessels to clot.
want: have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for
almond: the oval edible nutlike seed (kernel) of the almond tree, growing in a woody shell, widely used as food
pigment: the natural coloring matter of animal or plant tissue
mute: refraining from speech or temporarily speechless
laos: a landlocked country in Southeast Asia; population 6,800,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Laotian; capital, Vientiane.
cormorant: a large diving bird with a long neck, long hooked bill, short legs, and mainly dark plumage. It typically breeds on coastal cliffs and is noted for its voracious appetite.
input: what is put in, taken in, or operated on by any process or system
gremlin: an imaginary mischievous sprite regarded as responsible for an unexplained problem or fault, especially a mechanical or electronic one
musk: a strong-smelling reddish-brown substance which is secreted by the male musk deer for scent-marking and is an important ingredient in perfumery.
urinal: a bowl or other receptacle, typically attached to a wall in a public restroom, into which men may urinate.
kennedy: John F. (1917‚\u20AC\u201C63), US Democratic statesman, 35th president of the US 1961‚\u20AC\u201C3; full name John Fitzgerald Kennedy ; known as JFK. The youngest person to be elected to the presidency, he was a popular advocate of civil rights. In foreign affairs he recovered from the Bay of Pigs fiasco to demand successfully the withdrawal of Soviet missiles from Cuba during the Cuban Missile Crisis, October 18‚\u20AC\u201C29, 1962. On November 22, 1963, he was assassinated while riding in a motorcade through Dallas, Texas. Lee Harvey Oswald was charged with his murder.
volt: the SI unit of electromotive force, the difference of potential that would drive one ampere of current against one ohm resistance.
wane: (of the moon) have a progressively smaller part of its visible surface illuminated, so that it appears to decrease in size.
wand: a long, thin stick or rod.
butt: (of a person or animal) hit (someone or something) with the head or horns
bagpipe: a musical instrument with reed pipes that are sounded by the pressure of wind emitted from a bag squeezed by the player's arm. Bagpipes are associated especially with Scotland, but are also used in folk music in Ireland, Northumberland, and France.
crone: an old woman who is thin and ugly.
gadolinium: the chemical element of atomic number 64, a soft silvery-white metal of the lanthanide series.
cyclamen: a European plant of the primrose family, having pink, red, or white flowers with backward-curving petals and widely grown as a winter-flowering houseplant.
chivalrous: courteous and gallant, especially toward women (typically used of a man or his behavior)
reside: have one's permanent home in a particular place
ware: pottery, typically that of a specified type
ward: a separate room in a hospital, typically one allocated to a particular type of patient
hibernate: (of an animal or plant) spend the winter in a dormant state
chase: pursue in order to catch or catch up with
accident: an unfortunate incident that happens unexpectedly and unintentionally, typically resulting in damage or injury
anyway: used to confirm or support a point or idea just mentioned
ravine: a deep, narrow gorge with steep sides.
lectern: a tall stand with a sloping top to hold a book or notes, from which someone, typically a preacher or lecturer, can read while standing up.
lard: fat from the abdomen of a pig that is rendered and clarified for use in cooking.
knight: (in the Middle Ages) a man who served his sovereign or lord as a mounted soldier in armor.
inclement: (of the weather) unpleasantly cold or wet
lark: a small ground-dwelling songbird, typically with brown streaky plumage, a crest, and elongated hind claws, and with a song that is delivered in flight.
affability: the quality of having a friendly and good-natured manner
unawakened: not aware of or roused to particular sensations or feelings
inhibit: hinder, restrain, or prevent (an action or process)
dilapidate: cause (something) to fall into disrepair or ruin
evoke: bring or recall to the conscious mind
till: up to (the point in time or the event mentioned); until
tilt: move or cause to move into a sloping position
anymore: to any further extent; any longer
lynch: (of a mob) kill (someone), especially by hanging, for an alleged offense with or without a legal trial
wasp: a social winged insect that has a narrow waist and a sting. It constructs a paper nest from wood pulp and raises the larvae on a diet of insects.
nunnery: a building or group of buildings in which nuns live as a religious community; a convent.
late: doing something or taking place after the expected, proper, or usual time
tile: a thin rectangular slab of baked clay, concrete, or other material, used in overlapping rows for covering roofs
lath: a thin flat strip of wood, especially one of a series forming a foundation for the plaster of a wall or the tiles of a roof, or made into a trellis or fence.
keyword: a word or concept of great significance
brush: an implement with a handle, consisting of bristles, hair, or wire set into a block, used for cleaning or scrubbing, applying a liquid or powder to a surface, arranging the hair, or other purposes
prebend: the portion of the revenues of a cathedral or collegiate church formerly granted to a canon or member of the chapter as his stipend.
facsimile: an exact copy, especially of written or printed material
last: coming after all others in time or order; final
wary: feeling or showing caution about possible dangers or problems

wash: clean with water and, typically, soap or detergent
warn: inform someone in advance of an impending or possible danger, problem, or other unpleasant situation
warm: of or at a fairly or comfortably high temperature
lash: strike (someone) with a whip or stick
niter: potassium nitrate, especially as a naturally occurring mineral.
hyacinth: a bulbous plant of the lily family, with straplike leaves and a compact spike of bell-shaped fragrant flowers. Native to western Asia, hyacinths are cultivated outdoors and as houseplants.
wart: a small, hard, benign growth on the skin, caused by a virus.
swim: propel the body through water by using the limbs, or (in the case of a fish or other aquatic animal) by using fins, tail, or other bodily movement
pulsar: a celestial object, thought to be a rapidly rotating neutron star, that emits regular pulses of radio waves and other electromagnetic radiation at rates of up to one thousand pulses per second.
warp: become or cause to become bent or twisted out of shape, typically as a result of the effects of heat or dampness
inshore: at sea but close to the shore
radon: the chemical element of atomic number 86, a rare radioactive gas belonging to the noble gas series.
osseous: consisting of or turned into bone; ossified.
plural: (of a word or form) denoting more than one, or (in languages with dual number) more than two
taproom: a room in which alcoholic drinks, especially beer, are available on tap; a bar in a hotel or inn.
unmade: (of a bed) not having the bedclothes neatly arranged for sleeping in
bolero: a Spanish dance in simple triple time.
jewish: relating to, associated with, or denoting Jewish people or Judaism
video: the recording, reproducing, or broadcasting of moving visual images
dried: preserved by removal or evaporation of moisture
tint: a shade or variety of a color
ozone: a colorless unstable toxic gas with a pungent odor and powerful oxidizing properties, formed from oxygen by electrical discharges or ultraviolet light. It differs from normal oxygen (O‚\u201A\u201A) in having three atoms in its molecule (O‚\u201AÉ).
wave: move one's hand to and fro in greeting or as a signal
weapon: a thing designed or used for inflicting bodily harm or physical damage
lava: hot molten or semifluid rock erupted from a volcano or fissure, or solid rock resulting from cooling of this
ends: a neighborhood or urban area, especially one where a person lives or grew up

tine: a prong or sharp point, such as that on a fork or antler.
jacob: (in the Bible) a Hebrew patriarch, the younger of the twin sons of Isaac and Rebecca, who persuaded his brother Esau to sell him his birthright and tricked him out of his father's blessing. Jacob's twelve sons became the founders of the twelve tribes of ancient Israel.
vote: a formal indication of a choice between two or more candidates or courses of action, expressed typically through a ballot or a show of hands or by voice.
disease: a disorder of structure or function in a human, animal, or plant, especially one that has a known cause and a distinctive group of symptoms, signs, or anatomical changes

cuddle: hold close in one's arms as a way of showing love or affection
scull: each of a pair of small oars used by a single rower.
eponym: a person after whom a discovery, invention, place, etc., is named or thought to be named.
exult: feel or show triumphant elation or jubilation

alike: (of two or more subjects) similar to each other
disobedience: failure or refusal to obey rules or someone in authority

time: the indefinite continued progress of existence and events in the past, present, and future regarded as a whole

toluene: a colorless liquid hydrocarbon present in coal tar and petroleum and used as a solvent and in organic synthesis.

edification: the instruction or improvement of a person morally or intellectually

plinth: a heavy base supporting a statue or vase
unload: remove goods from (a vehicle, ship, container, etc.)

Dervishes first appeared in the 12th century; they were noted for their wild or ecstatic rituals and were known as dancing, whirling, or howling dervishes according to the practice of their order.

nonfiction: prose writing that is based on facts, real events, and real people, such as biography or history

marque: a make of car, as distinct from a specific model

wavy: having a form or edge that smoothly curves in and out
lawn: an area of short, mown grass in a yard, garden, or park

lazy: unwilling to work or use energy
cobalt: the chemical element of atomic number 27, a hard silvery-white magnetic metal.
unzip: unfasten the zipper of (an item of clothing)
alien: belonging to a foreign country or nation.
connate: (especially of ideas or principles) existing in a person or thing from birth; innate
laze: spend time in a relaxed, lazy manner
bucolic: relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life
uncultivated: (of land) not used for growing crops.
entice: attract or tempt by offering pleasure or advantage

chad: a piece of waste material removed from card or tape by punching.

sword: a weapon with a long metal blade and a hilt with a hand guard, used for thrusting or striking and now typically worn as part of ceremonial dress.

char: partially burn (an object) so as to blacken its surface

small: of a size that is less than normal or usual

beak: a bird's horny projecting jaws; a bill

fiction: literature in the form of prose that describes imaginary events and people.
bead: a small piece of glass, stone, or similar material, typically rounded and perforated for threading with others as a necklace or rosary or for sewing onto fabric
mead: an alcoholic drink of fermented honey and water
vulpine: relating to a fox or foxes

beat: strike (a person or an animal) repeatedly and violently so as to hurt or injure them, typically with an implement such as a club or whip

croak: a deep hoarse sound made by a frog or a crow
lounge: lie, sit, or stand in a relaxed or lazy way

enid: a city in north central Oklahoma; population 47,396 (est. 2008).

maturate: (of a boil, abscess, etc.) form pus
wagon: a vehicle used for transporting goods or another specified purpose
foppery: affected and excessive concern with one's clothes and appearance
stipend: a fixed regular sum paid as a salary or allowance.

point: the tapered, sharp end of a tool, weapon, or other object

It was the target of the first atom bomb, which was dropped by the US on August 6, 1945, and resulted in the deaths of about one third of the city's population of 300,000. This, with a second attack on Nagasaki three days later, led to Japan's surrender and to the end of World War II.

blame: assign responsibility for a fault or wrong
abet: encourage or assist (someone) to do something wrong, in particular, to commit a crime or other offense

lurid: very vivid in color, especially so as to create an unpleasantly harsh or unnatural effect
