outward: of, on, or from the outside
notice: the fact of observing or paying attention to something
disparage: regard or represent as being of little worth
bursar: a person who manages the financial affairs of a college or university.
asia: the largest of the world's continents, constituting nearly one third of the land mass, lying entirely north of the equator except for some Southeast Asian islands. It is connected to Africa by the Isthmus of Suez, and borders Europe (part of the same land mass) along the Ural Mountains and across the Caspian Sea.
sleazy: (of a person or situation) sordid, corrupt, or immoral
tuition: a sum of money charged for teaching or instruction by a school, college, or university
ashy: of a pale grayish color; ashen

envy: a feeling of discontented or resentful longing aroused by someone else's possessions, qualities, or luck

america: used as a name for the United States.

ineradicable: unable to be destroyed or removed
eight: equivalent to the product of two and four; one more than seven, or two less than ten; 8

illness: a disease or period of sickness affecting the body or mind

krone: the basic monetary unit of Denmark and Norway, equal to 100 √∏re.

A member of the Mohawk tribe, he is credited with establishing the Five Nations League, an Iroquois confederacy comprising the Onondaga, Mohawk, Oneida, Cayuga, and Seneca tribes. His name was used for the hero of Longfellow's narrative poem The Song of Hiawatha (1855).

agrarian: relating to cultivated land or the cultivation of land

neither: used before the first of two (or occasionally more) alternatives that are being specified (the others being introduced by ‚\u20ACúnor‚\u20AC?) to indicate that they are each untrue or each do not happen
domicile: the country that a person treats as their permanent home, or lives in and has a substantial connection with
bacillary: shaped like or consisting of a rod or rods
swivel: a coupling between two parts enabling one to revolve without turning the other.
pfennig: a monetary unit of Germany (until the introduction of the euro), equal to one hundredth of a mark.
diligence: careful and persistent work or effort
opine: hold and state as one's opinion
prefab: (especially of a building) manufactured in sections to enable assembly on site; prefabricated

fiat: a formal authorization or proposition; a decree

soft: easy to mold, cut, compress, or fold; not hard or firm to the touch
iris: a flat, colored, ring-shaped membrane behind the cornea of the eye, with an adjustable circular opening (pupil) in the center.
sofa: a long upholstered seat with a back and arms, for two or more people

loyal: giving or showing firm and constant support or allegiance to a person or institution
scoundrel: a dishonest or unscrupulous person; a rogue
july: the seventh month of the year, in the northern hemisphere usually considered the second month of summer
infra: (in a written document) below; further on
umbilical: relating to or affecting the navel or umbilical cord
sixpence: a coin worth six old pence, withdrawn in 1980.
yugoslavia: a former federal republic in southeastern Europe, in the Balkans.
trying: difficult or annoying; hard to endure
typhoid: an infectious bacterial fever with an eruption of red spots on the chest and abdomen and severe intestinal irritation.
soil: the upper layer of earth in which plants grow, a black or dark brown material typically consisting of a mixture of organic remains, clay, and rock particles
equable: (of a person) not easily disturbed or angered; calm and even-tempered.
tail: the hindmost part of an animal, especially when prolonged beyond the rest of the body, such as the flexible extension of the backbone in a vertebrate, the feathers at the hind end of a bird, or a terminal appendage in an insect
thursday: the day of the week before Friday and following Wednesday
mutter: say something in a low or barely audible voice, especially in dissatisfaction or irritation
june: the sixth month of the year, in the northern hemisphere usually considered the first month of summer

junk: old or discarded articles that are considered useless or of little value

laramie: a city in southeastern Wyoming; population 27,664 (est. 2008). It was first settled in 1868, during the construction of the Union Pacific Railroad.
purse: a small bag used especially by a woman to carry everyday personal items.

apathetic: showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern
moscow: the capital of Russia, located at the center of European Russia, on the Moskva River; population 10,470,300 (est. 2008). It became the capital when Ivan the Terrible proclaimed himself the first tsar in the 16th century. Peter the Great moved his capital to St. Petersburg in 1712, but, after the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917, Moscow was made the capital of the new Soviet government, with its center in the Kremlin.

fief: an estate of land, especially one held on condition of feudal service.
jura: a system of mountain ranges on the border of France and Switzerland. It has given its name to the Jurassic period, when most of its rocks were laid down.
bohemia: socially unconventional, artistic people and the areas they frequent, viewed collectively
glib: (of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow
hold: grasp, carry, or support with one's hands
tale: a fictitious or true narrative or story, especially one that is imaginatively recounted
trail: a mark or a series of signs or objects left behind by the passage of someone or something
prior: existing or coming before in time, order, or importance
hawse: the part of a ship's bows through which the anchor cables pass.
porpoise: a small toothed whale with a low triangular dorsal fin and a blunt rounded snout.
rubella: a contagious viral disease, with symptoms like mild measles. It can cause fetal malformation if contracted in early pregnancy.
talk: speak in order to give information or express ideas or feelings; converse or communicate by spoken words
tall: of great or more than average height, especially (with reference to an object) relative to width
iamb: a metrical foot consisting of one short (or unstressed) syllable followed by one long (or stressed) syllable.

ashore: to or on the shore from the direction of the sea

apiece: (used after a noun or an amount) to, for, or by each one of a group
jute: rough fiber made from the stems of a tropical Old World plant, used for making twine and rope or woven into sacking or matting.

tang: a strong taste, flavor, or smell

trot: (with reference to a horse or other four-legged animal) proceed or cause to proceed at a pace faster than a walk, lifting each diagonal pair of legs alternately
alpha: the first letter of the Greek alphabet (Œ\u2018, Œ±), transliterated as ‚\u20ACòa.‚\u20ACô.
tank: a large receptacle or storage chamber, especially for liquid or gas.
vaunt: boast about or praise (something), especially excessively
just: based on or behaving according to what is morally right and fair
troy: a system of weights used mainly for precious metals and gems, with a pound of 12 ounces or 5,760 grains
sole: the undersurface of a person's foot
atonal: not written in any key or mode
rembrandt: (1606‚\u20AC\u201C69), Dutch painter; full name Rembrandt Harmensz van Rijn. He established his reputation as a portrait painter with the Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Tulp (1632). In The Night Watch (1642), he used chiaroscuro to give his subjects a more spiritual and introspective quality. Rembrandt is identified with the series of more than sixty self-portraits painted from 1629 to 1669.
jury: a body of people (typically twelve in number) sworn to give a verdict in a legal case on the basis of evidence submitted to them in court
holy: dedicated or consecrated to God or a religious purpose; sacred

tamp: pack (a blast hole) full of clay or sand to concentrate the force of the explosion
solo: done by one person alone; unaccompanied
fife: a kind of small shrill flute used with the drum in military bands.

home: the place where one lives permanently, especially as a member of a family or household
ewer: a large jug with a wide mouth, formerly used for carrying water for someone to wash in.
hole: a hollow place in a solid body or surface
hypnosis: the induction of a state of consciousness in which a person apparently loses the power of voluntary action and is highly responsive to suggestion or direction. Its use in therapy, typically to recover suppressed memories or to allow modification of behavior by suggestion, has been revived but is still controversial.
prewar: existing, occurring, or built before a war
tame: (of an animal) not dangerous or frightened of people; domesticated
adjoin: be next to and joined with (a building, room, or piece of land)

holm: an islet, especially in a river or near a mainland.

moses: (fl.c.14th‚\u20AC\u201C13th centuries BC), Hebrew prophet and lawgiver, brother of Aaron. According to the biblical account, he was born in Egypt and led the Israelites away from servitude there, across the desert toward the Promised Land. During the journey he was inspired by God on Mount Sinai to write down the Ten Commandments on tablets of stone (Exod. 20).

In the south is Mount Sinai, where, according to the Bible, Moses received the Ten Commandments (Exod. 19‚\u20AC\u201C34).

The term is used chiefly of an intellectual movement of the 17th and 18th centuries that accepted the existence of a creator on the basis of reason but rejected belief in a supernatural deity who interacts with humankind.

online: controlled by or connected to another computer or to a network.

villa: (especially in continental Europe) a large and luxurious country residence.
glue: an adhesive substance used for sticking objects or materials together
enoch: (in the Bible) the eldest son of Cain.
scream: give a long, loud, piercing cry or cries expressing excitement, great emotion, or pain

It became part of the Mongol empire in the 13th century, was captured by the Russians in 1865, and replaced Samarkand as capital of Uzbekistan in 1930.

abandon: cease to support or look after (someone); desert

khan: a title given to rulers and officials in central Asia, Afghanistan, and certain other Muslim countries.
iberian: relating to or denoting Iberia, or the countries of Spain and Portugal.

cadge: ask for or obtain (something to which one is not strictly entitled)
inside: the inner side or surface of something

five: equivalent to the sum of two and three; one more than four, or half of ten; 5
oodles: a very great number or amount of something
lyceum: the garden at Athens in which Aristotle taught philosophy.

isbn: international standard book number, a ten-digit number assigned to every book before publication, recording such details as language, provenance, and publisher.

update: make (something) more modern or up to date
nitrate: a salt or ester of nitric acid, containing the anion NO‚\u201AÉ‚?ª or the group ‚\u20AC\u201DNO‚\u201AÉ
rouge: a red powder or cream used as a cosmetic for coloring the cheeks or lips.
amperage: the strength of an electric current in amperes.

causal: relating to or acting as a cause

wonder: a feeling of surprise mingled with admiration, caused by something beautiful, unexpected, unfamiliar, or inexplicable
corsage: a spray of flowers worn pinned to a woman's clothes.
entail: involve (something) as a necessary or inevitable part or consequence

rouen: a port on the Seine River in northwestern France, capital of Haute-Normandie; population 110,276 (2006). Rouen was in English possession from the time of the Norman Conquest until captured by the French in 1204, and again 1419‚\u20AC\u201C49; in 1431 Joan of Arc was tried and burned at the stake there.
exogenous: relating to or developing from external factors
coerce: persuade (an unwilling person) to do something by using force or threats

price: the amount of money expected, required, or given in payment for something

jeer: make rude and mocking remarks, typically in a loud voice

comma: a punctuation mark (,) indicating a pause between parts of a sentence. It is also used to separate items in a list and to mark the place of thousands in a large numeral.

spar: a thick, strong pole such as is used for a mast or yard on a ship.
span: the full extent of something from end to end; the amount of space that something covers
abbot: a man who is the head of an abbey of monks.

sagittarius: a large constellation (the Archer), said to represent a centaur carrying a bow and arrow. The center of the Galaxy is situated within it.

space: a continuous area or expanse which is free, available, or unoccupied

jodhpur: a city in western India, in Rajasthan; population 1,006,700 (est. 2009).

The order was zealous in opposing the Reformation. Despite periodic persecution it has retained an important influence in Catholic thought and education.

It is now rare in developed countries because of immunization.
vinyl: synthetic resin or plastic consisting of polyvinyl chloride or a related polymer, used for wallpapers and other covering materials and for \u007Frecords

bonn: a city in the state of North Rhine‚\u20AC\u201CWestphalia in Germany; population 314,300 (est. 2006). From 1949 until the reunification of Germany in 1990, it was the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany).

newborn: (of a child or animal) recently or just born

Formerly called Edo, it was the center of the military government under the shoguns 1603‚\u20AC\u201C1867. Renamed Tokyo in 1868, it replaced Kyoto as the imperial capital.

A leading cultural center of Moorish Spain, it was reclaimed by the Spanish in 1248, and rapidly became prominent as a center of trade with the colonies of the New World. Spanish name Sevilla.

esquire: a title appended to a lawyer's surname.
manganese: the chemical element of atomic number 25, a hard gray metal of the transition series. Manganese is an important component of special steels and magnetic alloys.
fjord: a long, narrow, deep inlet of the sea between high cliffs, as in Norway and Iceland, typically formed by submergence of a glaciated valley.
obligate: bind or compel (someone), especially legally or morally
hutch: a box or cage, typically with a wire mesh front, for keeping rabbits, ferrets, or other small domesticated animals
surreal: having the qualities of surrealism; bizarre
bissau: the capital of Guinea-Bissau, in the western part of the country; population 330,000 (est. 2007).
amid: surrounded by; in the middle of
chianti: a dry red wine, originally produced in Tuscany, Italy.
huckleberry: a small, round, edible blue-black berry related to the blueberry.
kebab: a dish of pieces of meat, fish, or vegetables roasted or grilled on a skewer or spit.
eurocheque: a check issued under an arrangement between European banks that enables account-holders from one country to use their checks in another.
stoke: add coal or other solid fuel to (a fire, furnace, boiler, etc.)
balsa: very lightweight wood used chiefly for making models and rafts.
unequal: not equal in quantity, size, or value
auricle: a structure resembling an ear or earlobe.
express: convey (a thought or feeling) in words or by gestures and conduct
ovum: a mature female reproductive cell, especially of a human or other animal, which can divide to give rise to an embryo usually only after fertilization by a male cell
garner: gather or collect (something, especially information or approval)
enclave: a portion of territory within or surrounded by a larger territory whose inhabitants are culturally or ethnically distinct
zero: no quantity or number; naught; the figure 0
burial: the action or practice of interring a dead body
nitwit: a silly or foolish person (often as a general term of abuse)
beaver: a large semiaquatic broad-tailed rodent that is native to North America and northern Eurasia. It is noted for its habit of gnawing through tree trunks to fell the trees in order to feed on the bark and build dams.
tuck: push, fold, or turn (the edges or ends of something, especially a garment or bedclothes) so as to hide them or hold them in place
anecdotal: (of an account) not necessarily true or reliable, because based on personal accounts rather than facts or research
otiose: serving no practical purpose or result
oracle: a priest or priestess acting as a medium through whom advice or prophecy was sought from the gods in classical antiquity.
horticultural: relating to the art or practice of garden cultivation and management
istanbul: a port in Turkey on the Bosporus that straddles Europe and Asia; population 10,757,300 (est. 2007). Formerly the Roman city of Constantinople 330‚\u20AC\u201C1453, it was built on the site of the ancient Greek city of Byzantium. It was captured by the Ottoman Turks in 1453 and was the capital of Turkey from that time until 1923.
dysentery: infection of the intestines resulting in severe diarrhea with the presence of blood and mucus in the feces.
drizzle: light rain falling in very fine drops
haifa: the chief port of Israel, in the northwest of the country on the Mediterranean coast; population 264,800 (est. 2008).
stole: a woman's long scarf or shawl, especially of fur or similar material, worn loosely over the shoulders.
ranch: a large farm, especially in the western US and Canada, where cattle or other animals are bred and raised
tube: a long, hollow cylinder of metal, plastic, glass, etc. for holding or transporting something, chiefly liquids or gases
ocean: a very large expanse of sea, in particular each of the main areas into which the sea is divided geographically
naval: of, in, or relating to a navy or navies
tuba: a large brass wind instrument of bass pitch, with three to six valves and a broad bell typically facing upward.
desk: a piece of furniture with a flat or sloped surface and typically with drawers, at which one can read, write, or do other work.
alfred: (849‚\u20AC\u201C99), king of Wessex 871‚\u20AC\u201C99; known as Alfred the Great. Alfred's military resistance saved southwestern England from Viking occupation. A great reformer, he is credited with the foundation of the English navy and with a revival of learning.
doing: the activities in which a particular person engages
abusable: Capable of being abused or misused; in later use frequently of alcohol, narcotics, etc.
bilinear: relating to or contained by two straight lines.
foxglove: a tall Eurasian plant with erect spikes of flowers, typically pinkish-purple or white, shaped like the fingers of gloves. It is a source of the drug digitalis.
lesotho: a landlocked mountainous country that forms an enclave in South Africa; population 2,100,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Maseru; official languages, Sesotho and English.
idea: a thought or suggestion as to a possible course of action
logjam: a crowded mass of logs blocking a river.
cicerone: a guide who gives information about antiquities and places of interest to sightseers.
fraternal: of or like a brother or brothers
flush: (of a person's skin, face, etc.) become red and hot, typically as the result of illness or strong emotion
herpes: any of a group of viral diseases caused by herpes viruses, affecting the skin (often with blisters) or the nervous system.
shyness: the quality or state of being shy
splurge: an act of spending money freely or extravagantly
unedited: (of material for publication or broadcasting) not edited.
tulip: a bulbous spring-flowering plant of the lily family, with boldly colored cup-shaped flowers.
twang: a strong ringing sound such as that made by the plucked string of a musical instrument or a released bowstring.
stone: hard solid nonmetallic mineral matter of which rock is made, especially as a building material
flute: a wind instrument made from a tube with holes along it that are stopped by the fingers or keys, held vertically or horizontally so that the player's breath strikes a narrow edge. The modern orchestral form, typically made of metal, is held horizontally and has an elaborate set of keys.
drought: a prolonged period of abnormally low rainfall, leading to a shortage of water
unbiased: showing no prejudice for or against something; impartial
pomade: a scented ointment or oil applied to the hair.
shibboleth: a custom, principle, or belief distinguishing a particular class or group of people, especially a long-standing one regarded as outmoded or no longer important
gynecologist: a physician or surgeon qualified to practice in gynecology.
tulsa: a port city on the Arkansas River in northeastern Oklahoma; population 385,635 (est. 2008).
yogurt: a semisolid food prepared from milk fermented by added bacteria, often sweetened and flavored
sack: a large bag made of a strong material such as burlap, thick paper, or plastic, used for storing and carrying goods.
epigenetic: relating to changes, especially heritable changes, in the characteristics of a cell or organism that result from altered gene expression or other effects not involving changes to the DNA sequence itself
ionosphere: the layer of the earth's atmosphere that contains a high concentration of ions and free electrons and is able to reflect radio waves. It lies above the mesosphere and extends from about 50 to 600 miles (80 to 1,000 km) above the earth's surface.
awash: covered or flooded with water, especially seawater or rain
bespatter: splash small drops of a liquid substance all over (an object or surface)
hack: cut with rough or heavy blows
jeroboam: a wine bottle with a capacity four times larger than that of an ordinary bottle.
road: a wide way leading from one place to another, especially one with a specially prepared surface which vehicles can use
review: a formal assessment or examination of something with the possibility or intention of instituting change if necessary
weather: the state of the atmosphere at a place and time as regards heat, dryness, sunshine, wind, rain, etc.
wrath: extreme anger (chiefly used for humorous or rhetorical effect)
roar: a full, deep, prolonged cry uttered by a lion or other large wild animal
roam: move about or travel aimlessly or unsystematically, especially over a wide area
nagoya: a city in central Japan, on the southern coast of the island of Honshu; population 2,154,287 (2007).
roan: denoting an animal, especially a horse or cow, having a coat of a main color thickly interspersed with hairs of another color, typically bay, chestnut, or black mixed with white
glasgow: a city in Scotland, on the Clyde River; population 578,700 (est. 2009). It is the largest city in Scotland.
ethnic: of or belonging to a population group or subgroup made up of people who share a common cultural background or descent
goal: (in football, soccer, rugby, hockey, and some other games) a pair of posts linked by a crossbar and often with a net attached behind it, forming a space into or over which the ball has to be sent in order to score.
protactinium: the chemical element of atomic number 91, a radioactive metal of the actinide series, occurring in small amounts as a product of the natural decay of uranium.
goat: a hardy domesticated ruminant animal that has backward curving horns and (in the male) a beard. It is kept for its milk and meat and is noted for its lively and frisky behavior.
beggar: a person, typically a homeless one, who lives by asking for money or food.
faust: (died c.1540), German astronomer and necromancer. Reputed to have sold his soul to the Devil, he became the subject of dramas by Marlowe and Goethe, an opera by Gounod, and a novel by Thomas Mann.
idem: used in citations to indicate an author or work that has just been mentioned
sphagnum: a plant of a genus that comprises the peat mosses.
ides: (in the ancient Roman calendar) a day falling roughly in the middle of each month (the 15th day of March, May, July, and October, and the 13th of other months) from which other dates were calculated.
tuft: a bunch or collection of threads, grass, hair, etc., held or growing together at the base
goad: provoke or annoy (someone) so as to stimulate some action or reaction
amos: a Hebrew minor prophet (c.760 BC), a shepherd of Tekoa, near Jerusalem.
vehemence: the display of strong feeling; passion
fluor: Such a mineral containing fluorine; especially = \"fluorspar\".
flag: a piece of cloth or similar material, typically oblong or square, attachable by one edge to a pole or rope and used as the symbol or emblem of a country or institution or as a decoration during public festivities
freight: goods transported in bulk by truck, train, ship, or aircraft
james: the name of seven Stuart kings of Scotland.
poultice: a soft, moist mass of material, typically of plant material or flour, applied to the body to relieve soreness and inflammation and kept in place with a cloth.
hobgoblin: (in mythology and fairy tales) a mischievous imp or sprite.
rock: the solid mineral material forming part of the surface of the earth and other similar planets, exposed on the surface or underlying the soil or oceans
flay: peel the skin off (a corpse or carcass)
flax: a blue-flowered herbaceous plant that is cultivated for its seed (linseed) and for textile fiber made from its stalks.
flaw: a mark, fault, or other imperfection that mars a substance or object
flat: smooth and even; without marked lumps or indentations
flap: (of a bird) move (its wings) up and down when flying or preparing to fly
flan: a baked dish consisting of an open-topped pastry case with a savory or sweet filling
blouse: a woman's loose upper garment resembling a shirt, typically with a collar, buttons, and sleeves.
skiing: the action of traveling over snow on skis, especially as a sport or recreation. Competitive skiing falls into two categories: Nordic (cross-country racing, jumping, and biathlon) and Alpine (downhill or straight racing, and slalom racing around a series of markers).
enamel: an opaque or semitransparent glassy substance applied to metallic or other hard surfaces for ornament or as a protective coating.
fritillary: a Eurasian plant of the lily family, with hanging bell-like flowers.
naphtha: a flammable oil containing various hydrocarbons, obtained by the dry distillation of organic substances such as coal, shale, or petroleum.
token: a thing serving as a visible or tangible representation of a fact, quality, feeling, etc.
filter: a porous device for removing impurities or solid particles from a liquid or gas passed through it
cease: bring or come to an end
emotion: a natural instinctive state of mind deriving from one's circumstances, mood, or relationships with others
etiquette: the customary code of polite behavior in society or among members of a particular profession or group
miser: a person who hoards wealth and spends as little money as possible
drape: arrange (cloth or clothing) loosely or casually on or around something
haggai: a Hebrew minor prophet of the 6th century BC.
slalom: a ski race down a winding course marked by flags or poles
arguable: able to be argued or asserted
redecorate: decorate (a room or building) again, typically differently
unutterable: too great, intense, or awful to describe
sago: edible starch which is obtained from a palm and is a staple food in parts of the tropics. The pith inside the trunk is scraped out, washed, and dried to produce a flour or processed to produce the granular sago used in the West.
fauna: the animals of a particular region, habitat, or geological period
nassau: a former duchy of western Germany from which the House of Orange arose.
hysterectomy: a surgical operation to remove all or part of the uterus
twelfth: constituting number twelve in a sequence; 12th
hygiene: conditions or practices conducive to maintaining health and preventing disease, especially through cleanliness
cologne: eau de cologne or scented toilet water
sage: an aromatic plant with grayish-green leaves that are used as a culinary herb, native to southern Europe and the Mediterranean.
tycoon: a wealthy, powerful person in business or industry
saga: a long story of heroic achievement, especially a medieval prose narrative in Old Norse or Old Icelandic
bitch: a female dog, wolf, fox, or otter.
suave: charming, confident, and elegant (typically used of a man)
crybaby: a person, especially a child, who sheds tears frequently or readily.
salmon: a large edible fish that is a popular game fish, much prized for its pink flesh. Salmon mature in the sea but migrate to freshwater streams to spawn.
bouquet: an attractively arranged bunch of flowers, especially one presented as a gift or carried at a ceremony.
delft: English or Dutch tin-glazed earthenware, typically decorated by hand in blue on a white background
ugly: unpleasant or repulsive, especially in appearance
dewberry: a trailing European bramble with soft prickles and edible fruit which has a dewy white bloom on the skin.
broach: raise (a sensitive or difficult subject) for discussion
safe: protected from or not exposed to danger or risk; not likely to be harmed or lost
reborn: brought back to life or activity
fragile: (of an object) easily broken or damaged
gideon: (in the Bible) an Israelite leader, described in Judges 6:11.
bedouin: a nomadic Arab of the desert
tuna: a large and active predatory schooling fish of the mackerel family. Found in warm seas, it is extensively fished commercially and is popular as a game fish.
raconteur: a person who tells anecdotes in a skillful and amusing way
sail: a piece of material extended on a mast to catch the wind and propel a boat or ship or other vessel
stout: (of a person) somewhat fat or of heavy build
flee: run away from a place or situation of danger
forage: (of a person or animal) search widely for food or provisions
graham: denoting or made from wholewheat flour that has not been sifted
flea: a small wingless jumping insect which feeds on the blood of mammals and birds. It sometimes transmits diseases through its bite, including plague and myxomatosis.
hedge: a fence or boundary formed by closely growing bushes or shrubs
tune: a melody, especially one that characterizes a particular piece of music
tench: a European freshwater fish of the minnow family, popular with anglers and widely introduced elsewhere, including several US states.
hair: any of the fine threadlike strands growing from the skin of humans, mammals, and some other animals
award: give or order the giving of (something) as an official payment, compensation, or prize to (someone)
flex: (with reference to a limb or joint) bend or become bent
stove: an apparatus for cooking or heating that operates by burning fuel or using electricity.
topped: having a top, topping, or surface of a specified kind
appraisal: an act of assessing something or someone
fluke: an unlikely chance occurrence, especially a surprising piece of luck
idly: with no particular purpose, reason, or foundation
filch: pilfer or steal (something, especially a thing of small value) in a casual way
february: the second month of the year, in the northern hemisphere usually considered the last month of winter
plight: a dangerous, difficult, or otherwise unfortunate situation
fault: an unattractive or unsatisfactory feature, especially in a piece of work or in a person's character
blithe: showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper
hail: pellets of frozen rain which fall in showers from cumulonimbus clouds
buccaneer: a pirate, originally off the Spanish American coasts
monsoon: a seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and Southeast Asia, blowing from the southwest between May and September and bringing rain (the wet monsoon), or from the northeast between October and April (the dry monsoon).
sunfish: a large deep-bodied marine fish of warm seas, with tall dorsal and anal fins near the rear of the body and a very short tail.
catnap: a short, light sleep; a doze.
rival: a person or thing competing with another for the same objective or for superiority in the same field of activity
